subject: Gardening
title: Cotton Seeds and Slavery
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Cotton Seeds and Slavery.

hook.text: The cotton gin made cotton seeds easy to process. It also made slavery enormously more profitable.

buildup.text: Before the gin (1793), separating cotton seeds from fiber was slow. Eli Whitney's machine made it 50 times faster.

discovery.text: Cotton production exploded. The US South went from 3,000 bales in 1790 to 4.5 million by 1860â€”all on enslaved labor.

twist.text: The gin was supposed to cut labor demand. Instead it massively increased itâ€”for land and for enslaved people.

climax.text: One mechanical seed innovation reshaped global economics, deepened human suffering, and helped cause a civil war.

punchline.text: A seed-processing invention prolonged slavery by decades.

quiz.question: What unintended consequence did the cotton gin have on American slavery?
options: It eliminated the need for enslaved labor in cotton production
It massively increased demand for enslaved labor by making cotton enormously profitable
It moved enslaved people from cotton fields into factory work
